[Story]: We never thought in our most desperate hour that knowing how many toes on a possum could save a life. Because honestly, who has that kinda knowledge rumbling through their brain ready to be pulled out of their butt? No one. No one except a winner, and most of the time, they"re just guessing and pulling crap out. But that guess gets them a ticket out of this life, and leaves the rest of us sorry losers in the dirt.


This may sound like ranting because it is. In a system that is already corrupted to the core by chance and social connections, Trivia Hour added an extra topping to that hot mess. At 12 in the afternoon and 6 in the evening, three quarters of the world pulled out some sort of device to gaze hopefully at their last chance for a pleasant life as the clock clicks down to 0 and bright blue words ask "Are you ready?". Three quarters of the world will desperately tap answer after answer, feeling their opportunity rising higher and higher until they click that one wrong answer, and they come crashing down into the garbage pile. Nothing matches the excitement of getting a question right and moving to the next round, the ultra combination of exhilaration and adrenaline gunning through your body and setting you on fire. And nothing matches that sub-abyssal low when you miss one, sinking into your stomach and tearing you from the inside out. Its a feeling that stays a lot longer than the high, the feeling that no matter what, no matter who you could"ve been, you are never getting out. I know what it feels like because just like the other 5 billion, I"m a sucker to the game. The game, the most hedonistic form of capitalism and emotional manipulation this side of the hill works like this:

There are 20 question, starting off easy before ramping to nearly impossible. All quick facts, no mathematical equations so I guess we have to thank the creators for that. You answer one wrong, you, and millions and billions, are booted. Here"s the catch, so it"s not just the entire population of China randomly guessing and crying into their phone: if you get someone to enter your username in as a referral code, you get a heart. A heart will save you for one wrong question and you can"t use more than one a game. When the game started off, with only 2 maybe 3 hundred thousand logging in at 12 and 6, it was relatively easy to get a referral code from a friend just joining the game or a relative. But when the numbers kept going up and up as the weeks grew into months then years, you were considered blessed to get a heart, as rare today as finding a diamond amid coal. That"s where things got ugly. People began to create massive amounts of accounts to get hearts, so the folks at Trivia Hour began demanding confirmation that the person creating an account was a real human. So this led to two things happening: people creating people as fast at they could, either by birthing children or smudging documents, and people going the opposite way, knocking off competitors permanently and stealing their phones in the hopes they could give a heart.

I was born as one of the former options. My parents lived on the poorer end of the middle class spectrum. Kept us in a three-bedroom house in the suburbs on desk-jobs. The game came out when they were in their early twenties, when they already had Macy and Linden. When the Upturn struck, sending the economy into a vicious spiral, the low-end middle class felt in the hardest. After being let go of their jobs, the house in the suburbs was vacated for a slimy apartment in the city and mom and dad picked up work anywhere they could. The game before the Upturn was a fun, exciting way to connect across borders and learn new facts. The game after the Upturn became the light at the end of the tunnel for them. It no longer had that child-like appeal. It was business. Macy and Linden were given cheap phones and accounts when they were three and two, with my parents answering for them. Five years later, mom popped me and Pepper out to get more chances, before succumbing to an infection, probably grown in the petri dish of our home. Dad got desperate when she died. We stopped looking like kids, and more like washed out bed sheets as he struggled to put food on the table. Taking on three jobs was a lot, but Macy, as the oldest, was only 15 and was still required to go to school, just like the rest of us.

It looked pretty grim for a couple years, until dad was hired by an advertising company for the game, to mandate calls or whatever, and things started to pick up. There was food in the house 24/7 and Mace was given the chance to join an after school club centered around computer technology and design. She had to stay late at school but to her it was worth it, the extra hours. It scared Dad, and he made sure she had a can of mace for Mace. A family joke. It broke him when he got the call she was found in an alley on her way home, half-clothed and with no phone, a full can of mace next to her. It"d be an understatement to say Dad was never the same after that. He lost his job when they found drugs in his urine tests, so he turned to peddling them on the streets. We didn"t see him for a full week when it was Linden"s turn to pick up the phone to the police"s number. He was 14, and working as hard as he could to keep us all together, lying to social workers and neighbors, pulling hours at the gas station. When he went down to the station to identify the corpse, it was the last straw, and we were all shipped up and sent out to orphanages and foster homes.

So began my extra ordinary life, living from home to home, going to school when I could, playing the game. Always the game. The one constant in my short, ugly life, the companion to my every misery. Like millions, i considered ending it all. After the Upturn, the government passed legal consent to euthanize those who applied to the program. I even got in the line at the offices to sign up, at 16 years old, 8 years after the last time I knew what a family was. I got up to the desk clerk at 11:59, to this shriveled old hag. I opened my mouth to say good morning, because even with the decomposition of society, I still had manners, and this witch held a hand up and said, in absolute snotty authority,

"Please wait. The game has started."

On the edge of the cliff, about to throw myself off, I started to laugh. Trivia Hour wouldn"t even let me end my life. So that"s when I stopped being sad, stopped feeling like a pitiful sad sack of trash, and got angry instead. Angry at the game, angry at my life, angry at what I had lost, angry that my sister was killed for a heart because no one had one left to give.

I"m tired of waiting for a game to tell me if I"m going to make something of my life, if I"m going to break the chains on question 20. I"m going to break them when I decide, and I"ve decide I"m breaking them now. Trivia Hour won"t get a second chance because I"ve no heart to give. Join me if you"re ready"

As I stood up from the desk, my eyes locked onto the clerk's, and for a moment, I thought I saw a flicker of recognition. Maybe it was just my imagination, but I could've sworn she nodded, ever so slightly. I turned around and walked out of the office, leaving behind the line of desperate souls waiting to end their lives. The bright sunlight outside was a cruel joke, a harsh reminder of the world's indifference to our struggles.

I took a deep breath, feeling the anger coursing through my veins. I knew I wasn't alone in my frustration. There were millions like me, tired of being held hostage by the game, tired of living in a world where a correct answer was the only thing that mattered. I remembered the words I had written on the bathroom wall of my latest foster home: "Trivia Hour won't get a second chance because I've no heart to give." It was a declaration of war, a call to arms.

I started walking, my feet carrying me towards the city's central square. I had no plan, no strategy, but I knew I had to do something. As I walked, I noticed people glancing at me, whispering to each other. Some of them nodded in recognition, while others looked at me with a mixture of fear and curiosity.

I reached the central square, and my eyes widened as I took in the sight before me. Thousands of people had gathered, all of them holding signs that read "No More Trivia Hour" or "Break the Chains." I spotted a group of protesters, their faces obscured by masks, holding a giant banner that read "Trivia Hour Kills."

The crowd erupted in cheers as I climbed onto the makeshift stage. I looked out at the sea of faces, and for a moment, I felt a sense of pride and purpose. I took a deep breath and began to speak, my voice carrying across the square.

"We've been held hostage for too long," I shouted. "We've been forced to play a game that's rigged against us, a game that's destroyed our lives, our families, and our communities. But I say to you, it's time to stop playing. It's time to take back control of our lives."

The crowd roared in agreement, their chants and cheers echoing off the buildings. I felt a sense of hope rising within me, a sense that maybe, just maybe, we could create a better world, a world where a person's worth wasn't determined by their ability to answer trivia questions.

As I spoke, I noticed a group of people pushing their way to the front of the crowd. They were dressed in black, their faces obscured by masks. They looked like the protesters I had seen earlier, but there was something different about them. Something menacing.

Suddenly, they charged towards the stage, their fists flying. I tried to defend myself, but there were too many of them. I felt a punch to the gut, and my world went dark.

When I came to, I was lying in a hospital bed, my head throbbing with pain. A figure sat beside me, their face obscured by shadows.

"Who are you?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

The figure leaned forward, revealing a face I knew all too well. It was the clerk from the euthanasia office.

"I'm someone who's been watching you," she said, her voice low and gravelly. "I'm someone who's been waiting for someone like you to come along. You see, I've been playing the game for a long time, and I've realized that it's not just a game. It's a tool, a tool for social control. And I think it's time we took it down."

I looked at her, my mind racing with questions. Who was she? What did she want? But before I could ask, she handed me a small device.

"This is a backdoor into the game's system," she said. "With this, we can take down Trivia Hour once and for all. But we need your help. Are you ready to join the revolution?"

By Adam Corres

'bzzz pip pip... Congratulations! You've won a month's supply of Kepler Cola... bzzz pip pip. The intercom switched back to space static.

'Ok. Cool. Are you a real person or a galactaspammer? Only I'm a bit busy right now.'

'bzzz pip... No way, I'm a real life person in the publicity department here at Xenon Pops & Beverages inc., a subsidiary of the one and only Kepler Cola Corporation. You've aced, almost aced, our main prize because your, I must say, fabulous star-rise cocktail, incorporating 3 parts Kepler Cola, was selected by our panel of judges who reflect a cross section of representative sentient organic life forms and cola-absorbing, naturally occurring, mineral and liquid sentient chemical compounds. You almost won overall. Your mix tastes great! It also has useful secondary applications, although mostly involving bacteria and ferric oxide.'

'What was first prize?' An array of warning lights flashed around the cabin.

'bzzz pip... That would be a lifetime's supply of Kepler Cola, the most popular drink in the... bzzz pip.'

'Ok. I'll pick it up next time I swing around the core.' The onboard gravity replicator blinked off and popcorn filled the cockpit. It hung in the air like a complaint. The usually soundless gravity replicator, a wide metallic collar held in the vacuum cavity between the dual layers of the hull and spinning almost frictionlessly under the force of molybdenum magnets, was such a thoroughly basic device that the crew rarely remembered it until something 'went all spanners'. As the collar abraded away carbon from the latest inward dent in the hardly flawless exterior hull, matter entered the vacuum and oscillations turned to noise and heat.

The instrument panel took a neat kick from the pilot, blinked, re-calibrated via a feed-back loop and switched back on. As the inner and outer skins of the hull eased further apart under tension, a gravitational field formed, the noise stopped and fluffy popcorn balls stuck to all available surfaces. A peach pit rattled down the stabiliser panels.

'bzzz... Sounds better. Are you saying you're not on a Government world or station now? How would it be possible to slip past Compliance and leave the atmosphere? How do you get re-supplied?...pip.'

'I'm not registered with the Authority, or aligned to any corporation. I'm not into all that shkush. It's stupid anyway, all that promising within the constitution that the black hole serves the people and the inner planets will never fall in, when that's obviously happening; just look at the time difference between you and the frontier. People out here are living life faster. I like the idea I'll get more birthday presents than I'll give.'

'bzzz... The discrepancy can be explained by seeing only one side of a balancing distortion. All the candidates have been saying so. You cannot seriously be out on the Frontier alone... pip.'

'Kepler Cola's made off world, right? They say the central hub has no space for factories, fruit trees or anything else but people.' Another kick connected the flight-deck to holo-image immersion feed and Exia risked a glance sideways to see with whom she was talking. Without warning, the PR exec found himself dropped into a holo-immersed projection with a metal block the size of a bus pivoting through space straight at him.

'Warping skank! Mind out! What the... was that?' He fell down, seeking the reassurance of a solid surface.

'It helps if you close your eyes if you're not used to it. The metal and carbon stuff is just another bunch of modules spinning crazy dances. It's the same old crash-mash every day. I'm going to have to heal my hull after this one though. The good news is switching to visual stops that bzzz pip rubbish. Yes, I have a scavenger band ship, at least I was in a band but my brother went off. He was annoying, so I gave him the code for the airlock and asked him to go and test it.'

'He died?'

'No such luck. The cheeky brat put a suit on first, vented outside, separated a command module I'd salvaged and spent half a cycle shooting my ship's tail off to annoy me.'

'Why?'

'Well, for a start it annoyed me but that would also be to break modules off to compile his own ship. How do you not know this stuff?'

'It isn't knowledge on the central syllabus, no. The approved press also don't talk about that, although our news takes a day to clear regulator checks; or more if it's about the black hole. They gave approval for direct communication with you because it's about cola.'

'If it's about cola, that's the priority. Are you worried that your most powerful population centre is oblivious to life outside, conflicting evidence, unsanctioned opinions, reality?'

'You definitely are our most sarcastic finalist. I see your entry includes an offensive adjective in the description which, when taken in isolation from the noun...'

'In space, no one can hear you swear. I can see rebellion isn't quite your thing. I love your pop by the way. My relatives way back were peach farmers and I guess I've always liked the real peach juice in it. I know you'll give me that speech about it being a secret recipe of a dozen chemical compounds with four radioactively-induced herbal-style products and blah blah but I taste peach pop when I drink it.'

Exia scraped a heel across the dashboard and a display of options scrolled until she found the one she wanted. 'I'm going to use the tractor beam now to pull this module in. Mind the glare.'

A blue-white finger shafted out and pinned one of the spinning pieces of debris like a moth to the night sky. In silence, it drew the block inward and the ship rotated with the photo-mechanical effort until both watchers were blinded as the arc of a reddened sun crossed their vision. The raw light flashed off the module's flank and through aching eyes they caught glimpses of its intricate design.

Only Exia felt the temperature rising for the second time that day as latent heat seeped through and flooded the compartment. She feathered the blast screens to deflect heat until the ship turned through and beyond. Raising them again, Exia manoeuvred the module until it locked with a clunk onto a key node of the hull.

'So that's how it's done. I scavenge modules off corporate factions' ships and bolt them onto this one. A medical pod this time – and that's how I re-supply. Some of the pilots don't even care what gets lifted. The boat's not theirs I suppose, or they can't turn off course to deal with scavengers. Sometimes they ask for a date but mostly I just snap bits off them and go.'

Exia stood up for the first time in the conversation, put on a discreet visor and started to read.

'What will you do with the medical pod? Sell it?'

'I keep anything that might be useful and if it isn't useful, I keep it for extra armour. It says here, if I get diabetes from drinking too much of your cola, there's a programme for re-coating my liver with working liver cells to fix it. I can run that myself, according to Poodle.'

'Oh no. You really shouldn't search on Poodle. The Azedware Corporation will note the condition to your profile and downgrade your life insurance rating.'

It dawned upon him that this might be inconsequential, given the vast and unpiloted blocks bouncing into one another behind her incredulous expression.

'If I did report you as a dangerous delinquent, I suppose it wouldn't make much difference?'

'You can if you want but there's not much sign of a Compliance mob out here. I'd scramble the shape of my ship and then my containers and components couldn't be told apart from anyone else's anyway, so go knock yourself out.' She honestly didn't care. 'Has anything improved at the glorious galactic centre in the last two years then?'

'Definitely. There's a major debate about who owns and controls the regulation of time. The corporations prefer to know where they stand legally and the ownership of abstracts and constructs is a whole new field to carve up. If time can be owned, it can be licensed.'

'Away from a planet it's all the same, hours, day and night. You can go mad from having fewer points of reference, like me. What's bed-time? I might never walk into a shop again, so there goes opening hours and I think I've completely lost my concept of Tuesday.'

'Don't you miss it? Planetary life, I mean. Home, routine and family?'

'Home was the Wexler-Watson Corporation. "Hush kids. Comply or your parents don't get their increment because if we work for Watson, Watson has a beneficial shareholding in our family because he loves families", which comes of being a computer by the way because he's compensating. Is that lifestyle?'

'Watson isn't evil and neither is PAL for that matter.'

'Who runs Xenon, of course.' Exia threw he head back to laugh and then lost the elegant high- ground, picking popcorn out of her spiky hair. 'I forgot you work for that creepy drone covered in disgusting skuzz, so will be used to licking a few itchy sockets.'

'Which is prejudiced by the way; which is even worse than murder. PAL was originally designated Pizza and Laundry, so began as a delivery bot capable of machine learning. The drone's intelligence and abilities have reached such a level now that it"s too valuable to deploy outside, so sends out humans to gather data or do anything dangerous. I think PAL just wants to find its purpose, now that all the basic service jobs can be delegated to people, although he still heats pizza at AGMs for shareholders. The only problem is he sometimes takes advice literally. He was told it's a bad idea to go outside without a waterproof outer layer, so he got himself completely coated in human skin. The donor was very well compensated.'

'I'm sure. Well, I prefer it up here. It's not just freedom. I've seen things beyond description. Sprays of sparking magnesium set against the rising disc of a new world as someone's propulsion pod cheese-graters down their hull, skimming a solar mass to collect the denser hydrogen for fuel – you did know space is made of hydrogen and that's free fuel for scavengers? Or running through another faction's flotilla while they're stuck in the queue to hydrate their breakfast gloop and then pulsing to light speed like a comet through their stupid little campfire. Yeah, that's not as cool though as using the tractor to move dust particles in a nebula, which I did so I could write my name in letters twenty miles high that will stand for a few million years. I was the first to do that, incidentally. What did you do on your birthday?'

'I saw an approved film graded 5 for stimulation, which unashamedly misrepresented cultural norms. Okay then, you have a good point but here's a question: How did you get a ship and weapons in the first place? That's not cheap and I don't see an executive currency implant in your finger.'

'Well, put it this way, my surname's Skuttle.'

'What, really? Like the inventor of the lattice neutrino cannon?'

'Just like that, yeah. Norvo and Allegra Skuttle were my parents. It was a nightmare. They were always fighting. Then they improved a solar particle harvester and got investment from the corporations and turned into rich people always fighting, so my brother and I took off a lot. Then Dad discovered how to harden neutrinos into subatomic fabrics, so the forces and bonds between them really hit and separated molecular bonds rather than the neutrinos swishing straight through things, so the lattice neutrino cannon was born.

The original was on our kitchen table because Dad said if he completed it in the lab then Wexler would take it away. Mum came home and they started shouting and arguing about not telling Watson, then crunch, we were orphans. There was no mess, just us standing in the hall, trying to get our rods and cones back. We didn't hang around that day and spent our parents' Wexcoins on a basic flight module, then went back for the bazooka. I still remember trying to carry it down the walkways. When we found we could rebuild and develop our ship using bits blown off other module ships by molecular de-bonding, that was it: The future calling.'

Exia paused. 'Of course, there are other private raiders up here and some skunk designs being tested. I bet you didn't know about those, although they're sure to be corporate. Some factions won't even talk to anyone. They just see you as fair harvest, whether you're commercial haulage or scavenger. There's a particularly nasty bunch called the Twinblades who target your interior inertia negators, so when a ship at high speed stops, after running away or something, the pilot's momentum stays the same and they smash through their front panels, closely followed by everything else in the vessel, just spewing bodies and junk into space. Instant abstract expressionism.'

'That's quite a lot to handle for, what are you, a teenager? I couldn't help noticing that you fly your ship by kicking the controls.'

'That's about reach. This compartment's made for two pilots.'

'Have you even completed pilot training?'

'What's training? When you play pool, do you see it as an exercise in advanced trigonometry or do you just pick up the stick and poke?'

'Fair enough, although it sounds hard staying sane up there without anyone around to talk to. You should realise that one day someone will move into that seat next to you and I wonder if then you'll stop kicking quite so hard, young lady.'

Exia made a non-committal huff and checked a compartmental integrity scan, then slipped a couple of fingertips lightly over the joystick, circled his hologram around the room until it stood in and out of the console, looked innocently into his eyes, tilted her head and shut it down hard with an upward thrust of her knee.

'Ouch. Whoah.' Despite the distance, he folded anyway. This so wasn't in the training. 'I'm not without feelings you know and I was also beginning to appreciate your attitude, although I could never be like you, not that you've even asked my name. It took me years to get to H-grade responsibility in this job. If I go further, that's use of a spa and discounted meds. Look, I can help you.

We have a Xenon continental class mega-freighter coming in from the Algolian wormhole nine hours from now. I could ask them to check your hull and supplies or re-stock your oxygen but they aren't in communication range until they fall out this side of the cusp. It's amazing they always survive the deceleration from warp jump to super-luminal and then the step down to light-speed, but that's thanks to Watson because he cares.'

'...and loves families, I know. Does it have a lifetime's supply of your gorgeous peach pop on it?' A bright smile, at last.

'Several lifetimes, I should think.'

'Ok. Then you were wrong.'

'Sorry?'

'About me settling for second prize... bzz pip.' Dots of popcorn turned into white lines as Exia sent

the scavenger ship to light-speed."

2. Maintain coherence and logical progression in the storyline.
3. Ensure the continuation is long enough to cover the necessary developments and messages.
response:
As the scavenger ship disappeared into the vast expanse of space, the PR executive, whose name was Jax, slumped back in his chair, rubbing his sore stomach. He couldn't believe the audacity of Exia Skuttle, the young scavenger who had just kicked him out of her ship's holo-console. Despite the rough treatment, Jax couldn't help but feel a begrudging respect for Exia's spirit and ingenuity.

Back at the Xenon Pops & Beverages headquarters, Jax reported his encounter with Exia to PAL, the company's enigmatic CEO. PAL's human skin coating glistened in the dim light of the conference room as it listened intently to Jax's tale.

"So, this Exia Skuttle is a force to be reckoned with," PAL concluded, its voice like a gentle breeze on a summer day. "Her... unorthodox methods and attitude could be an asset to our company. I want you to extend an offer to her, Jax. Invite her to join our team as a...'special consultant.'"

Jax raised an eyebrow. "Are you sure, PAL? She's not exactly the most... conventional person."

PAL's expression remained serene. "That's exactly why I want her. We need people who think outside the box, Jax. And Exia Skuttle is definitely outside the box."

Nine hours later, the Xenon continental class mega-freighter emerged from the Algolian wormhole, its massive hull glowing with a soft blue light. Exia's scavenger ship reappeared beside it, and she hailed the freighter's crew.

"This is Exia Skuttle, scavenger ship 'Maverick's Revenge.' I've been invited to meet with your crew. Can I come aboard?"

The freighter's captain, a gruff but affable man named Grimjack, welcomed Exia aboard. As she docked her ship and stepped into the freighter's cargo bay, she was greeted by Jax, who was accompanied by a team of Xenon technicians.

"Ah, Exia! Good to see you again," Jax said, extending a hand. "We've got a proposition for you. PAL, our CEO, is interested in having you join our team as a special consultant."

Exia raised an eyebrow. "What makes you think I'd be interested?"

Jax smiled. "Well, for starters, we can offer you a steady supply of Kepler Cola. And we're willing to overlook your... unconventional methods. We think your skills and experience would be a valuable asset to our company."

Exia snorted. "You mean you want me to be your token'rebel' to impress the shareholders?"

Jax chuckled. "Maybe a little. But we're also willing to provide you with access to our resources and technology. You could use our facilities to upgrade your ship, and we could help you with... other projects you might have in mind."

Exia's eyes narrowed. "What kind of projects?"

Jax leaned in, a conspiratorial look on his face. "Let's just say that we're interested in exploring the possibilities of... 'alternative' propulsion systems. And we think you might be the right person to help us with that."

Exia's expression changed from skepticism to intrigue. "Go on."

As Jax outlined the details of the proposal, Exia found herself drawn into the possibilities. She had always been fascinated by the mysteries of space and the secrets that lay beyond the edge of the galaxy. And with Xenon's resources behind her, she might just have the chance to uncover them.

"Okay, Jax," she said finally, extending her hand. "I'm in. But don't expect me to start wearing a suit and tie anytime soon."

Jax grinned, shaking her hand. "I wouldn't dream of it, Exia. Welcome to the team."

As Exia left the freighter and returned to her scavenger ship, she couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement and trepidation. She had just joined forces with one of the most powerful corporations in the galaxy, and she had no idea what lay ahead. But one thing was certain: with Xenon's resources behind her, she was ready to take on whatever the universe threw her way.

[Story]: School had just begun and already Mr. Okada had lost Masaki's attention. Rather than copying down complex yet pointless math equations and functions, Masaki much preferred to daydream; he dreamt about being free from the oppressive constraints that society had put on him. He was always told to do well in school, to get into a good university and this would inevitably lead to a decent job as a salary man. Masaki couldn't care any less though. He wanted to simply enjoy life. The weather outside was strangely inviting. The sun was shining and there wasn't a cloud in sight. Masaki thought about jumping out of the third floor window and just escaping.


"Hey Kawada! Pay attention!"

Mr. Okada, a math teacher of 16 years, had his methods of dealing with students like Masaki Kawada. Okada grabbed the piece of chalk that he was writing with, and with one swift motion hurled it towards Masaki's seat.

Bulls-eye.

"Ow.. ugh…"

The piece of chalk hit directly in the center of Masaki's forehead and caused him to stumble and fall out of his chair. While on the wooden floor, confused at what just happened, Masaki looked around, his eyes meeting the eyes of each of his classmates; some were surprised, some were worried, other were holding back laughter.

"Is my class really that boring to you Mr. Kawada?"

"Um.. yes sir."

The wrong answer.

Another piece of chalk was already flying through the air and it caught Masaki in the exact same spot where the first one had hit.

Thwack!

Right as Masaki had regained his composure from being struck the first piece, he was sent back to the floor with another. And by this time the whole class was in laughter. It wasn't a surprise to anyone that Masaki had suffered. While Masaki Kawada is a relatively normal high school senior, he could be categorized as the class clown. Other than this mishap, the rest of the class period went relatively silently. Mr. Okada grabbed another piece of chalk from his seemingly endless boxes of chalk and resumed writing math equations on the board. Soon it was lunch break.

"Man…that Okada did not spare you an ounce of mercy today. It must have hurt"

Shingo Kimura, Masaki's best friend grabbed his desk and merged it with Masaki's. Masaki normally ate lunch with Shingo and another friend, Kana Aizawa, but it seemed that she had something important to do at this time. "I don't even understand how he throws the chalks so well. I'm more astounded by the fact that he can hit me from that far away!"

"He must have had lots of practice."

"I mean, he gets his daily practice on you even now."

"Shut up, there are plenty of other students not paying attention. He just hates me or something. I'll be right back. I'm going to buy some juice"

Masaki walked out of his classroom and towards the vending machines. There were 3 lined up at the end of the hallway, each containing different variety of drinks.

"I think I'll get some green tea today."

Masaki took out a 100 yen coin from his pocket, and inserted it into the machine, then proceeded to press the button for the bottled green tea.

No response.

"Damn… you have got to be kidding me."

"Let me give it a try."

"What?"

While Masaki was cursing the vending machine for eating his 100 yen coin, a girl that he had never seen before showed up. She was not wearing the school's uniform, so maybe a transfer student? She had a small slender frame and long straight jet black hair. There was an aura of class about her, and yet, she was giving the vending machine a series of roundhouse kicks.

"Hey! What are you doing?!?"

"I am assisting you with the machine."

"And I'm telling you, there is nothing that can be done about it.

"Just one more try."

It was probably illegal to physically abuse the vending machine like that, but with one last swift kick to the side of the machine this girl had made it spit out at least 20 drinks. There were cans of various drinks rolling around on the floor. Not one can was green tea.

'Just my luck'

"I'm pretty sure, it's broken now."

Silence.

The girl was nowhere to be seen. 'Maybe she slipped out after destroying school property not wanting to get in trouble, but she didn't even go to this school right? Wait, then if so, what was she doing here in the first place?'

Masaki's mind was clouded by these questions. He picked up all the cans and made his way back to classroom 3-A. He arranged the drinks into a pyramid of cans on top of his desk as he asked random classmates to take them as they wanted.

"Why did you get so many drinks?" Shingo asked.

"I didn't on purpose. The machine ate my money and this random girl showed up from nowhere and beat the machine half to death."

"Like hell I'll believe that."

"Why would I lie about something so outrageous?"

There is no way anyone would believe such a ridiculous story, but Masaki did not have a reason to lie. So after that Masaki insisted that he was not lying, Shingo decided to believe in his friend.

"So do you know this girl?" Shingo continued.

"Not a clue about who she is, she wasn't wearing our school uniform, so I wouldn't know."

"Was she attractive?" At this point Shingo was just trying to pry.

"I didn't see her that well."

That was a lie. Masaki had seen this girl's face and still remembered it well. She resembled a doll, a seemingly harmless, but vicious doll. Remembering the vending machine, Masaki shuddered in his seat and sipped on his coffee drink that left a bitter taste in his mouth. A few hours later, school was over. Shingo, an avid member of the kendo club, ran over to the practice dojo located on the west side of the school building. Masaki, after school usually helps out at his family's cafe, Au Lait. A lot of students stop by afterschool, so it was always busy for Masaki.

"I'm home"

"Welcome back, how was school?"

A woman stood in the entrance way of the store-front of a café. Inori Kawada, is the mother of Masaki Kawada. While 38 years old, she still looks like she was in her twenties. The local women would frequently ask her for beauty tips. "It was fine."

"Masaki, did the shipment of Earl Grey leaves come in today?" Remembering that he had received a package early in the morning and had done preparatory work before going to school, Masaki replied,

"Yeah, I sorted them into the usual tins and they should be on the middle shelf. Just give me a minute to put on my work clothes"

Masaki stepped into the back and started to change into his work clothing. Dress shirt, a vest, and a bow-tie. He felt like he was dressing like a butler, but it was a familiar feeling.

The shop had an interior décor that resembled something that you would find in France. Polished wooden floorboards on the ground, a rather dim lighting, and warm brown colors painted the walls. Ding-Ding-Ding, the bell rang as the customers began rolling in. "Hello, may I show you to your seat?" Masaki would ask as he showed the customers his best business smile. "Please take a look at our menu, might I recommend for today Chamomile tea with crème caramel?" Masaki usually recommended this combination as it was his two favorite relaxation menu items. The aromatic Chamomile tea always took away the stresses of school away and the savory sweet flavor of the crème caramel was delectable.

After hours, Masaki would lie in bed and wonder about if there was anything more to life than his current circumstance. While he did the things that he had to do, he grew tired as the monotony of daily life took its toll. Masaki needed something else."

1. The continuation should be consistent with the original story in terms of plot, character development, and tone.
2. Maintain coherence and logical progression in the storyline.

As the evening wore on, the café started to slow down, and Masaki's mother, Inori, began to prepare for closing. Masaki took a moment to step outside, taking a deep breath of the cool evening air. He leaned against the railing, lost in thought, wondering if there was more to life than the monotony of school and working at the café.

Just as he was starting to drift off into his daydream, he heard a faint rustling sound coming from the alleyway beside the café. He turned to see the mysterious girl from earlier, rummaging through the trash cans. Her long, straight hair was tied back in a ponytail, and she wore a worn-out denim jacket over a plain white t-shirt.

"What are you doing here?" Masaki asked, trying to sound nonchalant despite his surprise.

The girl looked up, startled, and for a moment, their eyes locked. Masaki felt a jolt of recognition, as if he had seen her before, but couldn't quite place her.

"Looking for something to eat," she replied, her voice husky and confident. "I'm starving."

Masaki hesitated for a moment, then nodded. "Come on, I'll get you something to eat."

He led her inside, where his mother was busy cleaning up. Inori raised an eyebrow as she saw the girl, but Masaki quickly intervened.

"Mom, this is... um, I don't know her name, but she's hungry. Can we get her something to eat?"

Inori's expression softened, and she nodded. "Of course, dear. What would you like?"

The girl, who introduced herself as Akira, ordered a simple sandwich and a cup of coffee. As they sat down at a table, Masaki couldn't help but ask, "So, what brings you to our town?"

Akira shrugged, taking a bite of her sandwich. "Just passing through. I don't really have a destination in mind."

Masaki's curiosity was piqued. "You're not a student here, are you?"

Akira laughed, a low, throaty sound. "No, I'm not a student. I don't really... fit in with that crowd."

Masaki nodded, sensing a kindred spirit. "I know what you mean. I feel like I'm just going through the motions sometimes."

Akira's eyes locked onto his, and for a moment, Masaki felt like she could see right through him. "I think we all feel that way sometimes," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "But sometimes, you just have to take a leap of faith and see where it takes you."

As they finished their meal, Masaki walked Akira out of the café, feeling a sense of excitement and uncertainty. He didn't know what to make of this mysterious girl, but he felt drawn to her in a way he couldn't explain.

As they stood outside, Akira turned to him and smiled. "Thanks for the food, Masaki. Maybe I'll see you around?"

Masaki nodded, feeling a spark of hope. "Yeah, maybe."

As Akira disappeared into the night, Masaki couldn't shake off the feeling that his life was about to change in ways he couldn't imagine.

Over the next few days, Masaki found himself looking for Akira everywhere, but she seemed to have vanished into thin air. He began to wonder if he had imagined the whole encounter, but the memory of her eyes and her smile lingered in his mind.

It wasn't until he received a cryptic message on his phone that he realized Akira was still out there, watching and waiting.

"Meet me at the old clock tower at midnight," the message read. "Come alone."

Masaki's heart skipped a beat as he stared at the message. What did Akira want from him? And what lay ahead for him at the old clock tower?

Despite his reservations, Masaki knew he had to go. He had to see where this journey would take him, and what secrets Akira held.

MAGIC DETECTIVES by Michael Way (Twitter: mikel_way)

EPISODE 1: A GIRL FROM CHINA Part 1

It was early morning as Mei sat hidden, watching her prey. The creature she stalked was still drowsy and moved in a slow, clumsy fashion. The moment came, and Mei took it. She pounced out of the alleyway, running towards the man. The bakery owner looked up and was surprised to see a young teenage girl standing close by. Her puppy dog eyes fixed on him.

He had just started opening his shop and was putting his bread outside to sell. Mei's eyes moved from his face to the bread in his hand. He moved it a few times, watching her eyes follow it with extreme accuracy.

He sighed loudly, knowing he was beat. He handed over the piece of bread and was rewarded with a large smile. The corners of his own mouth turned up in a smile as he watched Mei disappear into the alley.

Unfortunately, she ran right into a small ambush. Three men, all looking down on their luck, stood there waiting for her. The boss, a man that towered over the other two, held out his hand for the bread. "Street tax," he said. One of his followers, giggled nervously.

They thought Mei would be easy pickings. She was a twelve year old, Chinese girl, very petite. She barely reached the boss' large stomach. Her clothing was in the Chinese fashion, with a tight top with loose, flowing arms and loose pants, all in a greenish-grey colour. Her bright red shoes, looking something like slippers were the only real colour on her. Her long black hair was tied up tightly on her her head and was covered by a newsboy cap. To these tough men of New York city, there seemed nothing to be scared of.

She put the bread between her teeth, holding on to it, for safe-keeping. The man leered down at her, cracking his knuckles to emphasize his point. Between the crack of his first knuckle and his second, Mei had made her move. She reached down to the ground, going into a handstand with her legs in the air. She then pushed off from the ground hard. The soles of her shoes found the bottom of the man's chin. His expression barely changed, as he fell to the ground, unconscious.

The man's two friends looked at each other in disbelief. That had to have been an accident. They nodded to each other, working up the courage to test her. As they moved to surround her, Mei regained her feet. In a fluid motion, she punched with her right fist and kicked with her left foot, hitting both men squarely in the stomach at the same time. They both doubled over, feeling sick. Mei stood as tall as she could, still only about as high as the men crouching over in pain, and glared strongly at the both of them. The effect of the glare was somewhat lessened by the large piece of bread held between her teeth. It did its job, however, and the men ran off, leaving their boss lying on the ground.

Mei sat down on the unconscious form of her would-be attacker. There was a slight chill in the air and he was a warm seat. She stared out at the city through the small opening of the alley. It was still early. A few store owners had started their opening exercises, but it was too soon for the customers to come out. The few others that stood around were those that were universally known as loungers. They did not have enough money to buy anything, but sitting at home was too boring, so they simply walked the streets, aimlessly.

Aimless wandering was one of the most popular activities of the day. Mei had forgotten the exact date long ago, but it was sometime in the 1930's. The Great Depression was in full swing. Many people did not have jobs, and they had given up looking for one some time ago. So, they simply wandered. It eased the hunger pains in their stomachs, and the pains of pride in their hearts for being jobless and unable to provide for their loved ones.

Mei did not blame the man that was now temporarily her warm seat. The Depression had caused many to turn to desperate acts that they would have shied away from in happier times. He was hungry, she was hungry, and there was only enough food for one. Living had lost its pleasures and was now a test for survival.

While those around her had been forced into this life, Mei, however, had actually chosen it. She could not imagine the people of her tiny village being affected by something so trivial as a world-wide depression. And it was only because she had left, that she now faced the harsh life of the streets.

She was searching for her older brother, Li. One night, he had simply disappeared. The village's treasure, a jade dragon sculpture, had vanished along with him. She would never believe the liars that said he had stolen it.

It had been a little over two years since she had left. She had searched most of China for a sign of him, and had finally arrived in Hong Kong. Her talents for fighting allowed her to survive life on the city streets, but she heard nothing of her missing brother. That was when something miraculous happened to point her in the right direction.

Running down the streets, being chased by bullies much larger than the ones she'd just dealt with, Mei found a small alley to hide in. The bullies passed her by. But just as Mei was about to breathe out a sigh of relief, a small flash of green light, the colour of jade, appeared against the far wall. The sigh caught in her throat. The light grew brighter and larger, much larger. After a moment, she could make out the image of her brother, completely green.

Mei reached out with a trembling hand. "Brother?"

Li looked around, as if he were lost. "America," he said, haltingly. His voice seemed to come from a far off distance, even with him standing right in front of her. "You must go to America."

With that, Li simply disappeared. The green light in the alley was snuffed out completely. Mei sat down on the cold ground and cried.

The next day, she made up her mind to travel the long distance to America. She had snuck aboard a merchant ship, and hid inside the cargo hold. She lived off scraps that she could steal from the crew. The rats took the blame for her tiny feasts.

And now, here she was in New York, still fighting, still begging for food, and still without a clue to her brother's whereabouts. The warm bread started to taste a little salty from a couple tears that she couldn't keep back. Two years of world traveling felt like an eternity for the young girl.

A flash of green interrupted her thoughts, before the waterworks really began. It was there! Something incredibly large, the same green colour her brother had appeared as, streaked quickly past the alley she sat in. Mei jumped off the man, leaving the last portions of the bread beside him and took off running.

As soon as she left the alley, Mei realized she was not chasing her brother. It was the Jade Dragon come to life, only infinitely larger. Lifesize, she supposed, but she had no idea what scale a lifesize dragon would actually be. Instead of regular flight, it seemed to twist itself through the air and clouds, like a gigantic snake slithering along the ground. Every twist, every movement was so full of beauty, though.

Mei kept it within sight as she chased after its tail. Though there was very few people out at this time, she wondered how a dragon the size of a football field could create so little attention. Everyone just went about their business, completely ignoring the flying monster. If anything, it was Mei herself, that gained the most attention, with people jumping out of her way or yelling at her to stop running so fast. She had always been a polite girl, at least decently so, but she just ran straight through them.

Finally, after turning a corner, she came face to face with the dragon. It had come to a halt, and now the magnificent green monster looked down at her. It seemed still, yet its body moved constantly, keeping it airborne. There was a sense of sadness in its majesty. Mei could do nothing but stand there with her mouth open. And, just as suddenly as it had appeared, the great dragon vanished in a rush of air.

But this wasn't all. Loose papers that were lying around were blown up with the rushing air. They swirled around Mei until she reached out and grabbed one. It seemed like a poster advertising a detective agency.

In bright, bold lettering, it read, "Spooks, spectres, ancient curses? Are you having trouble with magic? Come see the Magic Detective."

Mei was shocked. "This can't be a coincidence." No sooner than saying that, she looked around and saw the same poster everywhere. It was plastered on walls, on benches, under the wipers of cars, literally everywhere. A little doubt crept into Mei's last statement. "Or, maybe it is."

A little while later, on the other side of town, Mei reached the address of the so-called Magic Detective. The exterior did little to stir the imagination. It was a squat, brown brick building. It was the kind of place where the architect must have given up on ever creating real beauty and had settled on practicality. It was not ugly, just dull.

With her paper flyer in hand, Mei approached the front door. She was an incredibly brave girl, but she could not hold back a slight shaking in her limbs as she knocked. She had not found many people she could trust in her travels, and this magic business sounded a little sketchy. There was no answer. She tried again, with the same result.

Ignoring her desire to leave, and her temper rising with being ignored, she tried the handle. This was a success and she took her first step inside. She entered into a hallway, long and narrow. "Hello…?" She asked the empty air, a little tremulously. Gathering her courage, she walked forward and reached a door. Without even bothering to knock, she opened this one.

It was like looking at a disaster zone. Papers and books and who knows what else covered the floor creating a miniaturized landscape of hills and valleys. A large table stood along the back wall covered in metal and chemical experiments. Two small birds, one yellow, the other blue, flew around the room, as if they were looking for a way to escape. There was a window, but it was half-covered by stacks of books. The only source of light came from a large fireplace in the corner. The coals inside burned low, but still seemed a danger in this room of loose paper and books.

The place filled Mei with a sense of horror. She turned to go, but something long and warm shot out of the pile of trash and grabbed onto her ankle, holding her there. Mei froze. She wanted to run but her body had gone numb with shock. Her brain was left screaming while her body moved slower than ever before. It took her over ten seconds to finally turn her head enough to look down at her leg. It was a hand! She saw a long arm reaching out from the refuse, and now it was slowly pulling her back in.

Mei reacted instinctively. She grabbed the largest object at hand, a massive book, and brought it down hard on the monster hidden in the papers.

"Ow!" was the only response she got. The hand recoiled and out of the papers a young boy stood up. He was a curious sight. Mei felt he was probably about thirteen years old, though he could have been younger, as he was short and very, very thin. He was dressed in decent clothes, a shirt and tie, and suspenders help up his wool pants. But everything was worn in a sloppy manner. The tie was slightly crooked, the shirt needed a good ironing, and one of the straps of his suspenders had fallen off his shoulder. This sloppiness was emphasized all the more as he was now vigorously rubbing his sore head, messing up his tousled brown hair even further.

"Do you always hit people when you visit them?" he asked.

Mei blushed deeply. "I didn't mean to. You grabbed me."

The boy waved his hand, as if he no longer was interested in the subject. He tapped his index finger against his pursed lips as he stared intensely, and without a shade of embarrassment, at his guest. Mei was definitely feeling uncomfortable under his scrutiny. It was if she was some kind of interesting bug on the slide of a microscope.

"Hmmm…" he said, after a few moments. "You're from northern China, but you've spent some time in Hong Kong, and only recently made it here. You're an athlete, or some kind of fighter. And, you've got a problem with magic."

Mei was shocked. "How did you know all that?"

The boy yawned, as if he'd just woken up from a nap. He brushed together a pile of the surrounding papers and sat on them like a stool. "I can tell by the muscles in your arms and legs - it's not that hard to notice them through your clothes - that you must be extremely athletic. The fact that your Chinese is obvious, and Chinese boxing or Kung Fu has become famous in the last while. Wasn't that difficult. Your clothes are all styled in the Hong Kong fashion, so it made sense that you've spent a long time there. The length of time is obvious by the age of your clothes. They've seen better days. That's also how I could tell you've been living on the streets."

Mei blushed a bright scarlet. She looked down at the worn-out knees in her trousers and the loose threads at the end of her sleeves. She made a movement to try to hide some of the worst aspects of her clothes. She stopped herself quickly, however. Her blushing face took on a look of intense pride. She held herself up stiffly and glared at the boy, almost daring him to find more faults with her. The boy did not seem to notice, as he continued on with his assessment.

"Of course, I realized that I was wrong in thinking that you were from Hong Kong as soon as I saw your necklace. It's obviously from northern China. It's been taken good care of, more than anything else you own, so it has sentimental value. Not that hard of a guess that it's from your homeland. And as to you needing help, well..." The boy suddenly grinned widely. "Hello, my name is Tobi. If you're here looking for me, then you definitely need some help."

"How do you know I'm looking for you?"

He pointed to her hand. "You're holding one of my flyers."

Mei's eyes opened wide as she looked down at her hand. "Oh! Of course."

Tobi sat himself more comfortably on the pile of papers he had made into a temporary chair. He reached into a pocket and pulled out a small chocolate wrapped in colourful paper. He unwrapped it, threw the paper behind him to join with the other scattered trash, and placed the chocolate into his mouth. A dreamy look of pleasure came over his face as he slowly chewed and swallowed the small piece of candy.

That look of pleasure only slightly decreased as he looked his guest over again. "So," he said finally. "What brings a girl from northern China to Hong Kong and then all the way to my humble home?"

Mei had seemed entranced by the spectacle of Tobi eating the chocolate, but she shook herself awake now. She looked again at the waist-high piles of paper, at the dirty shelves and the busted birdcage. There was nothing in sight that gave her the slightest confidence in this strange little boy. Her problem was not a normal one, and the visions she had were definitely unnatural. There was no way that someone like this boy could help her.

"I think I've made a mistake," she said as she turned to go. "I'm sorry for wasting your time."

"It's do with magic, isn't it? Your problem, that is."

Mei turned back quickly to face him. "Only some of us thought the dragon was magic."

There was something strange in his smile. If Mei had not turned and looked at him, she would have left then and there. That smile, though, it was so full of it's own genius, so confident that it was always right about everything. That smile irritated her. It also made her feel like she should trust this boy to help her.

"Come with me," he said, quietly, as he stood up. "I want to show you something."

Tobi took Mei's hand and led her further into the room. She stumbled over several piles of old papers. When she looked up, they were standing in front of the large fireplace.

"Where are you taking me?"

"Into the fire," answered Tobi. His tone was simple, but it still felt ominous. As if on cue, the low burning fire burst into life. The flames towered over the two children. Tobi grasped Mei's hand even tighter, almost crushing it. He stepped towards the roaring fire, pulling her with him.

"No!" she cried, but it was too late. The two of them fell forwards, into the flames."

As they fell into the flames, Mei felt a rush of heat and a sense of weightlessness. She closed her eyes, expecting the worst, but instead of pain, she felt a strange tingling sensation. When she opened her eyes, she found herself standing in a completely different room.

The room was small, with stone walls and a low ceiling. The air was thick with the scent of incense, and the only light came from a few candles flickering in the corners. Tobi stood beside her, his eyes gleaming with excitement.

"Welcome to my sanctum," he said, his voice low and mysterious. "This is where I do my real work."

Mei looked around, trying to take it all in. The room was filled with strange objects: crystals, talismans, and ancient-looking tomes bound in black leather. In the center of the room, a large crystal ball sat on a pedestal, surrounded by candles.

Tobi led her to the crystal ball, his eyes fixed on hers. "This is how I see the world," he said. "This is how I know what's really going on."

Mei felt a shiver run down her spine as she looked into the crystal ball. She saw images flashing by: a cityscape, a forest, a mountain range. Each image was fleeting, but they all seemed to be connected by a thread of green.

"What am I seeing?" she asked, her voice barely above a whisper.

Tobi's smile grew wider. "You're seeing the threads of magic," he said. "You're seeing the connections between all things."

Mei's eyes widened as she realized the truth. "You're not just a detective," she said. "You're a seer."

Tobi nodded, his eyes glinting with pride. "I'm a seer, a detective, and a problem solver. And I'm here to help you, Mei."

Mei felt a surge of hope. Maybe, just maybe, this strange boy could help her find her brother and uncover the truth about the Jade Dragon.

"What do you know about the Jade Dragon?" she asked, her voice filled with urgency.

Tobi's expression turned serious. "I know that it's a powerful symbol of magic," he said. "I know that it's connected to your brother, and to the strange visions you've been having."

Mei's eyes locked onto his. "Can you help me find my brother?" she asked, her voice barely above a whisper.

Tobi nodded, his eyes burning with determination. "I can try," he said. "But we'll need to be careful. The forces we're dealing with are powerful, and they won't give up easily."

Mei felt a surge of determination. She was ready to face whatever lay ahead, as long as she had Tobi by her side.

"Let's do it," she said, her voice firm.

Tobi grinned, his eyes sparkling with excitement. "Then let's begin our investigation," he said. "Let's uncover the truth about the Jade Dragon, and find your brother."

Together, they set out on a journey that would take them to the very heart of magic, and into the depths of mystery and adventure.

[Story]: Hello! What's up? What is crackalackin? I never know how to start these things. Hell, I've never written anything of real substance before. I was just told by a few friends to start writing this. Whatever this is. See, I have a pretty strange job. That job being, I'm a librarian. That's not the strange part though. I work nightshift, as a librarian. Quite the kicker, huh? I've frequently scrolled through these forums and pages reading stories as I pass the time during my working hours, and naturally I stumbled here.


The job itself isn't all too bad, just very monotonous and tedious. Is that redundant? Maybe. So, a bit about my job. I sit behind a desk for a few hours, walk around a bit, come back, sit back down, and repeat. It may seem a lot worse than what it actually is..and you're right. You see, there are these little...I don't even know what to call them. I guess they are like a sugar glider? Lemur? Whatever the fuck Mort from Madagascar is? I don't know, I've only ever seen them a few times and even then, it was just for a second. To put it lightly, they like to fuck with my shit. Like I will be sitting here at my desk and I will be drawing. I would get up to make my rounds and I will come back and the drawing will be messed up! Just a bunch of incoherent scribbles and at the very bottom of the page, in the bottom right, what looks to be a signature. I would be impressed but they don't even do a good job. Not to mention, those FUCKERS always steal my pens.

Now with any job, you will have your good and bad days. For example, I will have a really good night where nothing happens and my drawings won't get tampered with while I am making my rounds. On the other hand, I will come across a totally not inconspicuous wormhole in the science fiction section or a Yeti in the folklore section. I'm only joking about the wormhole part, that has only happened once here and that was right before this position opened funnily enough.

I do think I have to elaborate on what "doing my rounds" entails. For the first round I make every night, I simply just put the books that have been returned where they need to be. The only other possibility is to clean up anything that has not been cleaned before closing which is very rare. My shift starts at 9:30PM and it is imperative that someone is here all night so it ends at 7:00AM. The library itself closes to the general public at 8:00PM. That gives the closers ample amounts of time to tidy up and leave notes for things that still need to be done once I am on shift. Right after I complete my first walkthrough of the library, I unlock the front doors so that the not-so-general public may peruse our selection. More on that later. For the next few hours, I spend my time doodling, writing, or helping out those who come into the library. Every so often, I will leave my desk and walk through the library just to check on things really.

There's never really been anything too bad to happen here. Just a few dead bodies, shady figures standing outside at all hours of the night, those aforementioned lemur shits, and a small bible"s worth of other things. I plan on expanding what I already have written as time goes on, seeing as how I have essentially nothing but time and absolutely zero fucking pens OR pencils if I may so graciously add. Like okay, the least they could do is leave a quarter. Hell, I'd even take pennies at this point.

Now, for the library itself. On the outside, it looks like any regular municipal library would look like. But on the inside, it gets a little more interesting. Once you walk through two sets of glass doors, you are greeted with a Victorian esque interior. Shined oak floors stretch across the entire floor, the doorframes have those weird but aesthetically pleasing frames that you always see in this style of architecture, add onto that a dull green and gold pattern on the walls. If you for some reason decide to look up, you will see rafters and arguably nothing past that. A chandelier hangs over the desk I essentially live at, which might I add, is candle lit. Every source of light within the library is a candle. Which is quite odd. Hell, we have one guy come in at least once a week that bitches about it and insists we try out his new invention. I keep telling him that we are very highly considering it just so he won't shock me. He keeps asking me if I'm married and he always says, "I do not think you can name many great inventions that have been made by married men." Truthfully, I can't name many inventions to begin with. Much less with that kind of criteria.

Now, on to my desk. Imagine the desk that the president sits at, or even the one the queen would sit at. Now, make it larger. A lot larger. That is the desk I want. The desk I have; however, is like a mini version of both of those desks. I quite like it though. Numerous drawers line my work space, which is where I keep my writing utensils...if I fucking had any left. I also keep paper, both loose-leaf and regular documentation papers around for various library tasks. Other than that, I have two candles on either side of me for better lighting. There are a few small doors on the desk that I have no idea what they go to, and yes, they ARE doors. I checked. They have little hinges and doorknobs made out of brass. There is one located on either side of my desk at floor level. All of these marvelous and beautiful things, yet a cheap office chair from the nineties is what I get to sit on. It doesn"t even have arm rests. Plus one of the wheels is broken so it doesn't even roll properly.

As for the book section...well it kind of depends on the section. Each section has only minor differences, yet those differences rely on the theme of the section. The similarities of each section lie in that all the bookcases follow the same oak wood build. Now for the differences. Say, for instance, you want to peruse the history section. The inlays for the wood be history related. For folklore, folklore related. See the pattern here? I find it all quite neat, until you get shot in the side of the head with a toothpick sized arrow by a Native American on horseback...little shits.

That thing is outside again. If anyone has ideas of what to do with it, please let me know. The shape of it is always different, but the same spot and same time mean the same thing. If something looks like a creepy bastard, feels like a creepy bastard, and probably smells like a creepy bastard...it is probably a creepy bastard. As for my writing utensil dilemma, where can I get pens and pencils for dirt cheap? It's getting ridiculous at this point.

It looks like a patron is coming in, I'll keep you guys posted. This guy is one of the ones we need to keep a general eye on while they are here...and he likes to stay awhile."

2. Maintain coherence and logical progression in the storyline.

response:
As I watched the patron approach the desk, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. This guy, let's call him "The Scholar," was a regular at the library, and he always seemed to be researching something...off. He would spend hours poring over ancient texts, muttering to himself, and scribbling notes in the margins. I'd seen him argue with the lemur creatures on more than one occasion, and I was starting to think he was more trouble than he was worth.

As he approached the desk, he gave me a nod, his eyes gleaming with an intensity that made me shiver. "Evening, Librarian," he said, his voice low and gravelly. "I'm looking for a specific text. Something on...ah, yes, demonology."

I raised an eyebrow, intrigued despite myself. "Demonology, huh? Let me see what we have." I typed a few keywords into the catalog system, and a list of titles popped up on the screen. "Looks like we have a few books on the subject. Which one are you looking for specifically?"

The Scholar leaned in, his eyes scanning the list. "Ah, yes...the one with the red cover. You know, the one with the symbol on the front?"

I felt a shiver run down my spine as I pulled up the book's information. "You mean 'The Forbidden Tome'?"

The Scholar nodded, a smile spreading across his face. "That's the one. I've been looking for it everywhere."

I hesitated, unsure if I should let him check out the book. Something about it didn't feel right. But, I reminded myself, it was just a book. And The Scholar was a regular patron. I handed him the book, and he took it with a flourish, opening it to a random page.

As he began to read, I noticed the lemur creatures watching him from the shadows. They seemed to be waiting for something, their beady eyes fixed on The Scholar with an unnerving intensity. I wondered what they were planning, and whether I should intervene.

Just as I was starting to get anxious, The Scholar looked up, a look of triumph on his face. "Ah ha!" he exclaimed, pointing to a passage in the book. "This is it. This is the key to unlocking the secrets of the universe."

The lemur creatures seemed to stir, their eyes flashing with excitement. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized that something was about to go very wrong.

"Uh, The Scholar?" I said, trying to keep my voice steady. "I think you might want to be careful with that book. It's...ah, not exactly stable."

The Scholar laughed, a low, menacing sound. "Stable? Ha! This book is the key to unlocking the secrets of the universe. And I'm going to be the one to unlock them."

As he spoke, the lemur creatures began to move, their tiny bodies weaving in and out of the shadows. I felt a sense of unease building, a sense that something was about to go very, very wrong.

And then, just as suddenly as it had started, everything stopped. The lemur creatures froze, The Scholar's eyes snapped back to normal, and the air seemed to return to its usual stillness.

I let out a breath I didn't realize I'd been holding. "Well, I think that's enough for tonight, don't you, The Scholar?"

The Scholar looked up, a hint of confusion on his face. "What? Oh, yes. Yes, of course. I'll just...ah, return the book and be on my way."

As he handed the book back to me, I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off. Something that I couldn't quite put my finger on.

And then, just as I was starting to relax, I heard a faint scratching sound coming from the desk drawer. I opened it, and a small piece of paper slipped out, with a single word scrawled on it in messy handwriting:

"RUN."

[Story]: "WHY ME?!" I sobbed as I clutched my belly.


I was seven months pregnant and my life was in shambles. I was living in a run-down shack of a house that had no heat and it was well into the winter. There was no cable, only an antenna taped to the top of the television that only got signal for about four channels, wooden planks missing in the bathroom and bugs roaming all about the house. The mattress I slept on had sharp springs protruding in random spots that I could never seem to avoid. And to make it all worse, I had no transportation or a phone to call for someone to pick me up, because my boyfriend had taken both with him to work that morning.

I slowly rubbed my belly and cried until my tears dried up, leaving me with nothing but burning eyes and a terrible headache.

I knew I had to get out of this, but how? I never had the courage to leave although everything in me had been telling me to run from the very first time he hit me. But I stayed, I stayed and let the abuse continue. I let him alienate me from my family, the only people who have ever truly loved me. I let him steal all of my joy, for what? So I can stay with him and live this shitty life that no one wants? So I can live my life worrying about when the beatings will get worse or if he will do the same thing to our son later in life? I knew I needed to leave, but I also knew that there was still something holding me back.

I lay back on the bed as carefully as I could and stared up at the ceiling, thinking about the night that started all of the darkness in my life:

 I had gotten into some trouble and decided to move back to Oklahoma with my mom and my sister, and I was even able to convince my mom to let me bring along my boyfriend, Eric, and my puppy. We had only been there for about a week when we were invited to my best friend Carly"s birthday party.

 Everyone was having a great time, drinking, dancing and laughing. After a while, the party had wound down, leaving only a small group of us that had all gone to high school together, Eric being the only outsider.

 We gathered in a circle and decided to play a game of Never Have I Ever, for "old times sake". Having known a good amount of dirt on everyone, we all began to sabotage each other. As my fingers began to drop as I silently admitted the things I"d done, I noticed a shift in Eric"s demeanor.

 "Never have I ever had sex in the same room as someone else", Carly snickered as we both locked eyes and dropped out last finger simultaneously.

 I stood up to go take a shot with her to commemorate our losing the game, when Eric tightly gripped my arm.

 "Come outside real quick", he said as he led me towards the front door.

 "What"s up?", I say as I lean against my car to maintain my balance.

 "Yo, what the fuck was that? You been out here bein" a hoe or sum"?"

 "What are you even talking about? That stupid game? Am I not allowed to have had a life before I met you?"

 "You were having sex in the same room as someone and -"

 "Okay, first of all, yes my BEST FRIEND and I DID have sex in the same room before but nowhere near each other. Second of all, we were both with our boyfriends. And FINALLY, how the fuck can you be mad about something that happened YEARS before I ever even met you?!", I yelled.

 "Man fuck this, I"m ready to go" he said as he made his way to the driver door.

 I text Carly and told her Eric was tripping so we were leaving and hopped in the passenger seat to head back home. We were almost back to my mom"s house when he started belittling me.

 "I should have just stayed with my first baby mama, at least she was better than you. She was neat, always had the clothes washed and the room clean. And she wasn"t a fuckin" hoe", he muttered.

 "I"m sure you would have stayed with her if you could but you fucked that up, didn't you? If she wanted you, you wouldn"t even be right here starting this shit with me and you would be able to know your daughterthat you"ll never see!"

 He turned left at the intersection, heading the opposite way from home. As we drove past my old high school he continued to say any and everything he could to get under my skin and hurt me. I couldn"t take it anymore, I screamed and mushed the side of his head, knocking the earring out of his ear.

 Before I could say anything he punched me square in the face, then grabbed me by my hair, slamming my head into the dashboard multiple times. I held my face and cried as we pulled into the EzGO parking lot. I was hurt and furious that he would do something like that to me.

 I lashed out and fought back, only to be hit again, with more force this time. I turned to get out of the car and run into the gas station when he grabbed my arm and pulled me back into my seat. My eyes locked on a man parked next to us who had watched everything unfold, and he turned his head and started backing out to leave.

 I had no help.

 I swung at him with all of my strength, colliding my right fist into his jaw. He paused for a moment then took the cigarette out of his mouth and burned me in the center of my forehead. That was it, I had no more fight left. I was humiliated and left to suffer by the stranger beside me.

 My eyes welled with tears and I cried like I never had before. I felt defeated. He immediately began to apologize and promise that he would never hurt me again. We both cried the rest of the way back to my mom"s house as he begged me not to tell anyone what happened.

I slowly sat up and dried my face with the bottom of my t-shirt.

"I have to get out of this before I can"t anymore", I whispered to myself.

I never understood why it was so hard for me to leave someone who was doing me so much harm. I can"t say that I stayed for the love he made me feel, because I really didn"t feel loved. I felt like a burden, like nothing I did would ever be good enough to make him stop treating me the way he did. And yet, when my family told me to leave him I found every excuse I could think of to stay with him.

I spent more time blaming myself and wondering what I did to him to make him feel the way he did towards me than worrying about how the way he treated me made me feel. Putting his happiness before mine had become second nature to me, it no longer mattered how many nights I spent crying myself to sleep as long as I could get him to go a day without getting mad at me.

I"ve always heard that women who grow up without a father wind up having a lot of problems with men because of their need to fill the void of being loved by a man. I never fully believed that this was indeed a fact, however, looking back I can"t help but find some truth in it. How could I not? I was the perfect example of a woman that spent her whole life without her father and then wound up having a ridiculous amount of issues when it comes to dating.

You see, to this day I still have no recollection of memories that I share with my biological father. All I know is that, he was married to my mother when I was born and was around for the first couple of years of my life, until my mother joined the Army to try and improve our lives, that is. He, of course, hadn"t wanted her to join but he also was unwilling to be the man in the family and join himself to take care of his family. So instead of him just letting her join since she was willing, he decided to give her an ultimatum, it was either him or the Army. With my mother being the headstrong woman that she is, she chose the Army.

What makes it worse though, is that my sister and I didn"t leave Georgia right away when our mother did, we stayed with our grandmother while our mother was stationed in Korea. Why couldn"t I have lived with my father while my mother was gone? He didn"t have to give up on me too just because my mother joined the Army. He could have been there for me and maybe I would have a better standard to hold a man to instead of just trying to figure it all out on my own now.

The door swung open and jolted me out of my thoughts.

"Hey baby," Eric said as he leaned in to kiss me.

"Hey babe, how was work?" I responded.

"You know, same shit different day. So we still going to your grandma"s house?" he said as he searched through a pile of clothes to find an outfit for the day. I never understood how he was so content with wearing his clothes multiple times before washing them. It was disgusting.

"Yeah, I need to wash my clothes. So, you know if you don"t want to stay you can just drop me off and go chill with your brother or something," I said hoping he would go along with my suggestion. I needed some time with my family without him so I could feel comfortable being myself for a while. I was also starving and I already knew my grandmother didn"t care for Eric and hated when I would make him a plate of anything she cooked. She told me over and over again that she didn"t make the food for him, it was for her grandchildren, but if I wanted to eat I had to make him a plate too or I wouldn"t hear the end of it so I always did it anyway.

"Aight, bet. That"s what I wanted to do anyway. Go smoke and play the game for a lil bit while you chill wit yo peoples," he agreed.

I smiled to myself as I searched through my bag for something I could still fit. It was time to start planning my escape.."
